So back in my early days of playing Guardian, my experience was, along with the experience of other people I talked to was, that the text on this is a bit misleading to what it's really good at doing. It mentions the AOE effect first, then the Brace. In reality, it is extremely hard to play this card in defensive mode, because you have to spend energy entering defensive mode, then you have to spend energy on this card. So most of the time, you will be playing this for the 8 Brace. This is fine though; 8 Brace is one of the largest Brace numbers on a single card, and is really important at all stages of the game in order to enter Defensive Mode.

Aside from that though, 2 energy for 16 damage seems low until you realize that Guardian's playstyle is mostly slower than other characters due to their defensive nature, so cards with lower damage numbers than most other characters is actually perfectly fine. In fact, this is one of the most efficient damage cards Guardian has, at least for its rarity. It's a great Act 1 card, but if you need Brace in the later game and have extra energy or stasis, this card is still takeable, although the 2 energy cost is still pricey.

It also has a socket, which is very unusual, because it costs 2 energy, which severely limits which gems can be effectively taken advantage of. There are probably some use cases for most gems, but failing those rare situations, defensive Gems and Citrine (energy) are probably the best ones to have here.

Overall, this card is great, solid B-tier, maybe A-tier depending on your definition.

While I've been doing the 100 Guardian series, I was very surprised by how I ended up with a deck where my main engine was Roll Attack. The combination of large damage and large brace numbers can cover both offense and defense under the right situation. There was luck involved with how the deck was able to function beyond that, but I had no idea this card could do something like that. https://youtu.be/Lbqt4FrjoYc

Most cards are worse at low ascensions and Skip is better on low ascensions (where good = clicking it increases your chance to win); this is true of the vanilla game as well but is particularly notable for Downfall and doubly so for Guardian. (I think arguably this is the worst facet of Slay the Spire's design, because Skip is not very fun or intuitively appealing, so it's not great for it to be so often the best option, but nothing is perfect)

messages.content: I wonder how strong this is (without some random modpack that introduces OP relics for no reason)

If we're talking about fundamental flaws in this game's design, I'd say the big one is that all the strikes and defends mean that decks don't differentiate a lot until near the end of act 1. The example I'd point to as an alternative is Monster Train (admittedly released well after this game became a trendsetter). There, the equivalent of Ascension 1 adds several random cards to your deck at the beginning of the run, and you also always get a few random goodies before the first fight, so that from the word go your deck is different each time.

if we're talking about this particular card, I'm not sure I've ever taken it. A 2 energy attack that deals less than 20 damage and doesn't scale much looks pretty scary. It's possible I just haven't given it its fair shake though.
thats actually the thing that turns me off the most about monster train
i dont want random junk in my deck i want to actually build my deck
theres a lot of things in monster train where the things you do dont feel intentional
Yeah most top level play, especially speedruns involves resetting for 5 minutes until you get a run, and that's lame
and if I get a really bad combo I don't feel incentivized to try and make it work, I reset. There is no punishment like not getting full neow options unless you made it to the act 1 boss
Also with units doing the primary parts of your damage on 90% of your builds, each turn doesn't really feel as impactful.

I absolutely love monster trains covenant 1 modifier, because it encourages trying out new cards, and puts you into unique situations very early in the run, giving you the chance to adapt and demonstrate your flexibility to work with what you've been given. So many card games feature A+B synergies (Like silents discard outlets and cards that care about discarding), but can run into weird chicken and egg problems where it never feels great to take A or B cards without already having the other, meaning you take neither. Starting with some already in the deck can encourage getting into those synergies, and allow the player to feel more willing to try out unusual synergies they don't have experience with. Transforms in slay the spire fill a very similar role, which I also really enjoy.

It is worth noting that Monster train also gives the player so many more opportunities to remove cards from their deck, and has several starter cards that are actually pretty good and don't need to be removed (torch, rootseeds, forgone power, primitive mold, fracture, echo break). You also have the +20 magic power and consume upgrade, which can make several of the starter cards much more reasonable, and gets them out of the way of your first reshuffle. All of this is to say, that even if covenant 1 rolls you some pretty weird/awkward cards, you can still remove them fairly reasonably.
It's easier to just reset though. After a while once I've tried most things and I see something that's just really bad/unfun and I see it, I reset.
I think that if you are to give people any sort of randomness they are forced to deal with, you need to have some way of disincentivizing resets or the game will just be reset-heavy
ah yes
Eden Tokens were made to prevent people from Holding R too much as Eden
I mean, monster train does track your win streak if you care about that
at several different difficulty tiers
but mostly, I just figure it's more fun to roll with whatever it gives you early on
I don't really care what speedrunners do when playing casually
The whole relying on units thing... I wouldn't say that's a flaw per se, but it does point to the way that your deck will usually hinge on an extremely rigid setup which is more of a flaw

I usually try and play games casually, but I'm just a naturally competitive player. I don't care about a winstreak or anything, it's mostly an intrinsic motivation to win as much as often as I can, I don't really care about winrate.
And working with stuff that will brick you late game (sorry for the offensive terminology) just isn't fun to me
I never research metas or anything, I just play games, and sometimes if I find something really effective but boring I still use it
When I'm bored I watch videos on game design, and it's pretty easily explained. Players just optimize the fun out of the game.

For me, part of the fun is trying to make something interesting/non-optimal work. I am always thrilled when I can include weird/niche cards into a deck (flex, firebeathing, outmaneuver, concentrate, aggregate, hello world, study, swivel) and give them an opportunity to shine. I do agree that you can end up optimizing the fun out if you reset frequently, or just laser focus in on one strategy, but you can also have a lot of fun by making a weird/unusual deck. It just depends on what your goals are when playing, and for me, a huge part of what I love about slay the spire/monster train is playing the run you are in, working with what you see, trying to make the best of a challenging set of cards/relics.

Roll attack is a deceptively good card in my opinion. It looks innocuous enough, but it tends to overperform in my experience. 8 is just a huge amount of brace, and can frequently help you to mitigate damage between this turn and the next. The AOE component is difficult to trigger intentionally, but can be some nice value if you have other big brace cards/powers, 4 energy, or guardian gear. It's also a little easier to trigger now than it used to be thanks to gear up from your starter relic. What I really like though is the damage. Guardian can really struggle to deal enough damage in the early game, with all your starting defends, curl up, and possibly a few unsocketed gems, so being able to saturate 2 energy into a big attack is something that I put a premium on. Guardian can often do a good job of stalling and blocking in act 1, but you need to draw enough damage to end fights in a reasonable time frame, and roll attack is excellent at helping you do that, and the upgrade also helps significantly with that.

The socket isn't quite as easy to get value from as some other guardian cards, since you need to spend 2 energy to get the effect, so ruby/emerald/quartz are all harder to use with it. It can however add a nice bit of extra efficiency to the card, by putting in fragmented gem, sapphire, aquamarine, amethyst or citrine. The socket can also help roll attack transition even more gracefully into the late game, where the damage isn't as useful anymore, but you can still get value from the brace, and potentially mitigation from a amethyst or aquamarine. 

It's excellent into all 3 act 1 elites, often helping you to block for 20 in a timely fashion, while dealing 16 to the enemy. Any access to vulnerable (potion, steam vents, garnet) can really amplify that damage as well. You can't rely on the aoe for tri-sentries, but it can happen if you draw well, and is really impactful when it happens. The aoe is also good into the act 2 elites as well, especially at 4 energy.

It's insane with necronomicon, and runic pyramid is also really useful with it to line up the aoe/brace for the right turns. Great with snecko eye, since the effect is very high impact. Can be decent with the ninja relics if you put fragmented gem into it.

if you're calling firebreathing niche you'd better be talking about old firebreathing. New firebreathing was the crutch that got me through A17-A20 as vanilla Ironclad (not every one of those levels but at least two of them were won this way) and is absurdly powerful in the right deck

honestly beyond the thoughts (both positive/negative) others shared, I think it's one of the more balanced cards in downfall

only thing that is tricky about it (which I like) is the 2 energy cost, like if it had 50% of all the numerical stuff and cost 1, it would absolutely be a bomb card, but it makes early game choices pretty narrow after you pick up one of these
a card you'll never take twice, but is decent to put 1 in the deck
what about 7 times

@Brickman I was talking about current firebreathing, which can absolutely be a great card in the right deck. I do think it's fairly niche though, because you really want to have enough access to status generation/curses to help it out, and an evolve to help draw past the statuses. It can be taken blindly against slime boss, or if you just fought a non-senties elite in act 1, since it's so good into tri-sentries. In general though, I probably don't find a good opportunity to include firebreathing in roughly 75 percent of ironclad runs, which is why I'm excited when I can find a good home for it.
